fields.description:
In AWS, all non-VPC ELBs reside in the same security group whose name is {{amazon-elb-sg}} and whose account is {{amazon-elb}}.  The standard procedure for authorizing traffic inbound to back end instances from ELB involves creating a security group rule that refers to this group.

Eucalyptus's implementation puts every ELB in its own security group.  While I might be able to figure out what account owns ELB security groups, I have no documented way of predicting what group names I have to use, and certainly no way that is remotely compatible with AWS.  Consequently, at best I have to open my back end instances up to all instances in the cloud.  If I don't know what IP space the cloud uses, though, I have to open my back end instances to the entire Internet to be sure that ELB is going to work.

This issue is critical because it breaks the default procedure for authorizing traffic from ELB to back end instances.  Moreover, it has a high likelihood of forcing people to allow their back end instances to be directly accessible from the Internet.

An alternative fix for this is to make Eucalyptus's ELBs behave like those that appear in EC2 default VPCs, using user-controlled security groups instead.
fields.summary: All ELBs should be in the same, well-known security group

comments.body: Created KB Article - [Eucalyptus vs. AWS - Differences in Ingress Security Group Authorization for Elastic Load Balancing (ELB)|https://support.eucalyptus.com/hc/en-us/articles/202221554]

"I have no documented way of predicting what group names I have to use"
Security group name is a part of describe-loadbalancers response (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/APIReference/API_LoadBalancerDescription.html) . While I agree that it's better to use the same *convention* as AWS, the clients would better use the name in the euca-descibe-loadbalancer response  (the protocol).

And implementing "ALL ELB in the same security group" requires non-trivial changes, because security group in the current ELB is used to selectively open a port for incoming traffic. Using security group for this purpose is our practical choice (an implementation detail not mandated by AWS spec).

AWS have updated their ELB user guide to recommend that people look up the info for their load balancers' security group names rather than simply entering well-known info.  As such, I am lowering this issue's severity.
[~kedwards] [~gholms] [~hspencer] IMO, there is no chance that this can be done in 4.1.

In the implementation detail, if we put all ELBs for an account to have the same security group, that will result in opening the aggregated set of ports to each LB VMs.
In other words, some LB VM will have a port open even though the LB's not configured to do so.

I'm not sure if this statement is or will be true: "Moreover, it has a high likelihood of forcing people to allow their back end instances to be directly accessible from the Internet." 

We don't break the AWS protocol, but do not follow their convention because it's more complex to implement and it's less secure.
[~spark], I see your point. Can you clarify how can one currently authorize access to a backend instance from an LB only without making the backend instance public-facing?
[~spark], never mind, I see that the security group name follows a convention. Changing the priority back to the original value. Thanks!

[~rusvika] It's to use the same procedure as AWS.

Call eulb-describe-lbs to get the security group name(and the owner) of the LB.

[root@thinkpad spark]# eulb-describe-lbs --show-long
LOAD_BALANCER	sparklb	sparklb-250940146638.lb.thinkpad			{interval=30,target=TCP:80,timeout=5,healthy-threshold=3,unhealthy-threshold=2}	PARTI00		i-167002ed,i-6b9efe0f	{protocol=HTTP,lb-port=80,instance-port=80}					{owner-alias=290623922235,group-name=euca-internal-250940146638-sparklb}		2014-11-05T19:57:27.728Z	internet-facing

Then call authorize with the source owner and the group option.
euca-authorize -u 290623922235 -o euca-internal-250940146638-sparklb

This differs from AWS:
euca-authorize -u amazon-elb -o amazon-elb-sg

This issue is for the EC2-Classic platform, EC2-VPC works differently for ELB security groups:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/USVPC_ApplySG.html
Will not be able to redo ELB with the time left.

This is a blocker for viewing non-VPC ELBs in the console (GUI-1483).  Without this, viewing a non-VPC ELB will return a 500 error due to the missing source_security_group property.

[~kedwards], could we escalate this and target for 4.2?

[~kgill] Not sure why this would be a blocker. When you do "DescribeLoadbalancers" on the ELB, it will return the name of the security group in SourceSecurityGroup element. The naming is the convention and we follow the protocol.

<DescribeLoadBalancersResponse xmlns="http://elasticloadbalancing.amazonaws.com/doc/2012-06-01/"><DescribeLoadBalancersResult><LoadBalancerDescriptions><member><LoadBalancerName>sparklb06</LoadBalancerName><DNSName>sparklb06-000019943619.lb.e-11.autoqa.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com</DNSName><ListenerDescriptions><member><Listener><Protocol>HTTP</Protocol><LoadBalancerPort>80</LoadBalancerPort><InstancePort>8000</InstancePort></Listener><PolicyNames/></member></ListenerDescriptions><Policies><AppCookieStickinessPolicies/><LBCookieStickinessPolicies/><OtherPolicies/></Policies><BackendServerDescriptions/><AvailabilityZones><member>one</member></AvailabilityZones><HealthCheck><Target>TCP:8000</Target><Interval>30</Interval><Timeout>5</Timeout><UnhealthyThreshold>2</UnhealthyThreshold><HealthyThreshold>3</HealthyThreshold></HealthCheck><SourceSecurityGroup><OwnerAlias>000003998494</OwnerAlias><GroupName>euca-internal-000019943619-sparklb06</GroupName></SourceSecurityGroup><CreatedTime>2015-05-28T22:55:07.066Z</CreatedTime><Scheme>internet-facing</Scheme></member></LoadBalancerDescriptions></DescribeLoadBalancersResult><ResponseMetadata><RequestId>9fa86b72-7ffb-4721-a94b-4faa7bfe931d::d1b0a33e-7ffc-4be6-b9f6-f9f59f9cb686</RequestId></ResponseMetadata></DescribeLoadBalancersResponse>
[~spark]: This is for the ELB detail page, which returns None for the elb.source_security_group property for a non-VPC ELB (tested on the 10.111.5.150 cloud with ui-test-acct-00/admin).

[~kgill] Here's the XML response on 10.111.5.150. Is the error from boto?

<DescribeLoadBalancersResponse xmlns="http://elasticloadbalancing.amazonaws.com/doc/2012-06-01/"><DescribeLoadBalancersResult><LoadBalancerDescriptions><member><LoadBalancerName>test-elb-0011</LoadBalancerName><DNSName>test-elb-0011-827379074989.lb.g-08-08.qa1.eucalyptus-systems.com</DNSName><ListenerDescriptions><member><Listener><Protocol>HTTP</Protocol><LoadBalancerPort>80</LoadBalancerPort><InstanceProtocol>HTTP</InstanceProtocol><InstancePort>80</InstancePort></Listener><PolicyNames/></member><member><Listener><Protocol>HTTP</Protocol><LoadBalancerPort>8080</LoadBalancerPort><InstanceProtocol>HTTP</InstanceProtocol><InstancePort>8080</InstancePort></Listener><PolicyNames/></member></ListenerDescriptions><Policies><AppCookieStickinessPolicies/><LBCookieStickinessPolicies/><OtherPolicies/></Policies><BackendServerDescriptions/><AvailabilityZones><member>one</member></AvailabilityZones><Instances><member><InstanceId>i-a68930a5</InstanceId></member><member><InstanceId>i-c214ee58</InstanceId></member></Instances><HealthCheck><Target>HTTP:80//index.html</Target><Interval>30</Interval><Timeout>7</Timeout><UnhealthyThreshold>3</UnhealthyThreshold><HealthyThreshold>10</HealthyThreshold></HealthCheck>*<SourceSecurityGroup><OwnerAlias>044186861095</OwnerAlias><GroupName>euca-internal-827379074989-test-elb-0011</GroupName></SourceSecurityGroup>*<CreatedTime>2015-05-14T23:47:44.567Z</CreatedTime><Scheme>internet-facing</Scheme></member></LoadBalancerDescriptions></DescribeLoadBalancersResult><ResponseMetadata><RequestId>f6f628db-235c-4c07-ac58-30db6499b93a::65c70f6d-235d-4dae-ae12-cb354951b9ed</RequestId></ResponseMetadata></DescribeLoadBalancersResponse>
[~spark], [~kedwards]: Thanks for the updates.  This may be a boto issue, continuing to investigate...

[~kedwards], [~spark], [~jloza], [~dkavanagh]: Sorry for the false alarm folks, looks as though the cause of the issue in the console was an errant non-VPC ELB that was created (without a source security group) a while back when our create ELB wizard wasn't quite fully implemented.
[~kgill] fyi, non-VPC ELB will always create a source security group automatically and expose it via DescribeLoadBalancers API.

[~spark]: Understood.  I don't know the cause of the missing source security group in the errant ELB on the 5.150 cloud, but were having trouble deleting it via the console and euca2ools.  I suspect the deletion attempt returns an Internal Error due to the missing source security group, but I'm not clear about that.  See my comments in GUI-1485 if you're curious about the deletion issue we're observing there.
